qas.question: What does the runway consist of?
What does improving visibilitiy by using a right handed pattern do for the ATC?
What does usually using a right-handed pattern as standard help pilots do?

context: Generally, this pattern is a circuit consisting of <b6_0>five "legs" that form a rectangle<b6_0/> (two legs and the runway form one side, with the remaining legs forming three more sides). Each leg is named (see diagram), and ATC directs pilots on how to join and leave the circuit. Traffic patterns are flown at one specific altitude, <b4_0>usually <a0_0>800 or 1,000 ft<a0_0/> (244 or 305 m)<b4_0/> <a1_0>above ground level<a1_0/> (AGL). <a3_0>Standard traffic patterns are <a2_0>left-handed<a3_0/><a2_0/>, meaning all turns are made to the left. One of the main reason for this is that <b5_0>pilots sit on the left side of the airplane, and a Left-hand patterns improves their visibility of the airport and pattern<b5_0/>. Right-handed patterns do exist, usually because of obstacles such as a mountain, or to reduce noise for local residents. The predetermined circuit <b7_0>helps traffic flow smoothly<b7_0/> because all pilots <b8_0>know what to expect<b8_0/>, and helps reduce the chance of a mid-air collision.
